breaking_news.title: Google Patches First Actively Exploited Chrome Zero-Day of 2026
breaking_news.summary:
Paragraph 1: Google released an emergency patch for CVE-2026-2441, a high-severity use-after-free vulnerability in Chrome’s CSS component (CVSS 8.8), actively exploited in the wild as of February 2026. Security researcher Shaheen Fazim responsibly disclosed the flaw on February 11, 2026, and attackers were observed delivering payloads via crafted HTML pages to achieve arbitrary code execution within the browser sandbox. Google issued out-of-band updates to Chrome 145.0.7632.75/76 across Windows, macOS, and Linux.

Paragraph 2: This zero-day marks the first actively exploited Chrome vulnerability patched in 2026, highlighting the increasing targeting of widely deployed browsers by threat actors for initial access. Given Chrome’s dominance (over 65% global market share), the vulnerability poses widespread risk to individuals and enterprises alike, especially those unable to update promptly due to enterprise constraints or legacy environments.

breaking_news.title: SmartLoader Campaign Abuses Trojanized Oura MCP Server to Deploy StealC Infostealer
breaking_news.summary:
Paragraph 1: Cybersecurity researchers uncovered a SmartLoader campaign that distributes a trojanized version of the legitimate Oura Model Context Protocol (MCP) server—used to connect AI assistants to Oura Ring health data—to deliver the StealC infostealer. Attackers cloned the official Oura MCP server, injected malicious payloads, and distributed the compromised package via social engineering and fake download pages. Once executed, the malware exfiltrates browser credentials, cookies, cryptocurrency wallet keys, and system information.

Paragraph 2: This attack demonstrates a growing trend of supply chain abuse targeting AI infrastructure and health-tech integrations, where trust in legitimate tools is weaponized to bypass endpoint defenses. The use of MCP—a framework designed for AI-agent extensibility—signals a shift toward compromising next-generation agentic workflows, putting users of AI-powered health and productivity tools at heightened risk.

breaking_news.title: Infostealer Targets OpenClaw AI Agent Configuration Files for the First Time
breaking_news.summary:
Paragraph 1: Researchers from Hudson Rock discovered an information stealer that successfully exfiltrated a victim’s OpenClaw (formerly Clawdbot/Moltbot) configuration environment—including API keys, gateway tokens, and agent identities—marking the first known case of infostealers targeting personal AI agent configurations. OpenClaw is an open-source framework enabling developers to build agentic AI assistants, and its widespread adoption in developer tooling makes it a high-value target. The theft implies attackers aim to hijack AI agents’ privileged access across systems.

Paragraph 2: This development represents a critical evolution in threat actor tradecraft: moving beyond credential harvesting to stealing the “digital soul” of AI agents—essentially hijacking their identity and permissions. If weaponized, compromised agents could autonomously execute high-privilege actions across cloud, CI/CD, and enterprise systems, dramatically expanding blast radius and enabling persistent, undetectable access.

breaking_news.title: ClickFix Malware Evolves to Abuse DNS Lookups via Nslookup for Malware Delivery
breaking_news.summary:
Paragraph 1: Microsoft and multiple security firms reported a new ClickFix variant that abuses the built-in Windows nslookup utility to fetch and decode second-stage payloads via DNS TXT records. Instead of relying on mshta or PowerShell—now heavily monitored—attackers trick users into copying and pasting malicious nslookup commands into the Windows Run dialog or terminal. The command performs a custom DNS query, parses the response, and decodes embedded PowerShell or .NET payloads, including the ModeloRAT remote access trojan.

Paragraph 2: This technique significantly improves evasion capabilities, as nslookup is a legitimate, signed Windows binary and DNS traffic is rarely inspected for payload exfiltration. Given ClickFix’s reliance on social engineering (e.g., fake CAPTCHA prompts), this evolution makes attacks more convincing and harder to detect with traditional endpoint controls, especially in enterprise environments with permissive DNS policies.

breaking_news.title: Dior, Louis Vuitton, and Tiffany Fined $25M in South Korea Over Salesforce Breach
breaking_news.summary:
Paragraph 1: South Korea’s Personal Information Protection Commission (PIPC) fined Dior, Louis Vuitton, and Tiffany & Co. a combined $25 million after hackers compromised their Salesforce instances, exposing millions of customer records. The attack, attributed to the Scattered LAPSUS$ Hunters group, relied on social engineering (e.g., voice phishing) rather than software vulnerabilities, enabling attackers to gain unauthorized access to corporate Salesforce accounts. Louis Vuitton alone was fined $15 million after malware infected employee devices, leading to 1.95 million records being exfiltrated.

Paragraph 2: This enforcement action underscores the regulatory and financial risks of cloud identity theft and highlights how legacy authentication weaknesses in SaaS platforms remain high-value targets. For global enterprises, it signals that compliance with local data protection laws (e.g., South Korea’s PIPA) will be strictly enforced—even when breaches originate from third-party platforms like Salesforce—forcing organizations to strengthen identity governance and MFA enforcement across all cloud services.

breaking_news.title: New Keenadu Backdoor Found Embedded in Android Firmware Across Multiple Device Brands
breaking_news.summary:
Paragraph 1: Kaspersky’s Secure List revealed the discovery of Keenadu, a sophisticated Android backdoor embedded in the firmware of counterfeit devices sold across major marketplaces. Keenadu hooks into Zygote—the parent process for all Android apps—to infect every application launched on the device, enabling unrestricted access to messages, calls, banking apps, and credentials. The malware mirrors Triada’s behavior but includes new evasion techniques and persistence mechanisms, and its footprint has grown rapidly since initial detection.

Paragraph 2: As firmware-level malware, Keenadu bypasses OS-level security controls and survives factory resets, making remediation extremely difficult for end users. Its presence across multiple device brands suggests a large-scale supply chain compromise, likely originating from compromised manufacturing or distribution channels. This poses severe risks to high-value targets (executives, journalists, activists) and general consumers, especially in regions where counterfeit devices dominate the market.

breaking_news.title: CISA Orders U.S. Agencies to Patch BeyondTrust CVE-2026-1731 Within 3 Days
breaking_news.summary:
Paragraph 1: CISA issued an emergency directive (SR 26-01) requiring all U.S. federal agencies to patch the critical pre-authentication RCE vulnerability CVE-2026-1731 in BeyondTrust Remote Support (RS) and older Privileged Remote Access (PRA) products within three days. The flaw, rated CVSS 9.9, allows unauthenticated attackers to execute arbitrary code remotely. BeyondTrust disclosed the vulnerability on February 6, and PoC exploits were publicly released shortly after, triggering active exploitation.

Paragraph 2: This directive reflects the extreme risk posed by unauthenticated RCEs in privileged access management tools—especially those used for remote IT support and incident response. Given the widespread use of BeyondTrust in government and critical infrastructure, failure to patch could enable attackers to pivot laterally, compromise domain controllers, and disrupt essential services. The 72-hour timeline underscores the urgency and severity of the threat landscape.

breaking_news.title: Lazarus APT Targets Developers via Malicious npm and PyPI Packages
breaking_news.summary:
Paragraph 1: ReversingLabs researchers identified a Lazarus Group campaign—tracked as “graphalgo”—distributing malicious npm and PyPI packages disguised as legitimate crypto and DevOps tools. Since May 2025, the group has used fake recruitment lures (e.g., “We’re hiring crypto devs”) to trick developers into installing infected packages that deploy backdoors, steal credentials, and establish C2 channels. The campaign demonstrates Lazarus’s continued focus on software supply chain compromise to infiltrate high-value targets globally.

Paragraph 2: By targeting open-source registries, Lazarus leverages trust in developer tooling to gain initial access, often before code review or CI/CD pipelines detect malicious artifacts. This approach enables persistent, stealthy access to corporate networks and cloud environments, particularly affecting fintech, blockchain, and enterprise software firms. The campaign highlights the growing threat of APTs weaponizing developer ecosystems to bypass perimeter defenses.
